awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Meteor Plasma Formation and Dynamics with Implication for Radar Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's upper atmosphere is densely populated by molecular, atomic and ionized meteors. These particles are important for maintaining the conductivity of the E region ionosphere (~90-150 km). They can be sensed using radio and optical methods, and therefore provide a great deal of information about the state of the upper atmosphere and the extraterrestrial environments of their origin. However, current estimates of total meteoric input are accurate only to within approximately two orders of magnitude. It is important to improve upon such estimates, since meteor chemistry affects Earth from roughly 150 km above the surface all the way down to the ice cores. 

The research will apply radar data and first-principles computer models to trace the evolution of meteor plasma in the ionosphere. The project will support a full-time graduate student and an undergraduate. The Principal Investigators (PIs)' work will yield knowledge of the types of meteors that contribute most to Earth's upper atmosphere. This information is important to Space scientists, engineers, and astronomers. Spacecraft designers need to know the distribution of particle orbits and masses in order to mitigate potential hazards. Meteor population characteristics provides greater understanding of the evolution and composition of the outer solar system. The PIs and co-PI will continue their efforts to share their knowledge and enthusiasm about space and meteor science with the larger community through outreach to K-12 schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to improve characterization of meteoroids entering the Earth’s atmosphere through radar observations. Earth's upper atmosphere is densely populated by molecular, atomic and ionized meteoric materials. These particles are important for maintaining the conductivity of the E region ionosphere (~90-150 km). They can be sensed using radio and optical methods, and therefore provide a great deal of information about the state of the upper atmosphere and the extraterrestrial environments of their origin. However, current estimates of total meteoric input are accurate only to within approximately two orders of magnitude. It is important to improve upon such estimates, since meteor chemistry affects Earth from roughly 150 km above the surface all the way down to the ice cores. Improving the global mass flux estimates, however, requires better assessment of individual particles observed by radar.

In this work, we updated an existing numerical model with more physical meteor plasma distributions; allowed for the rotation of the meteor plasma in the simulation space, to account for different meteor trajectories; and added the ability to simulate radar returns at different ground locations. A key outcome of our modeling work is a more robust FDTD model of meteor head echo scattering that can be applied to current and future datasets to extract more information and insight from meteor observations.

We performed hundreds of simulations across a reasonable parameter space and built up lookup tables that relate a unique combination of plasma parameters to measured radar returns. These tables allow a user to take their measured radar signals and estimate the meteor plasma density directly. The measured radar return is then compared to model results to estimate the meteor size; the plasma distribution is then fully defined and mass can be calculated for each event.

We have applied this technique to a dataset of several hundred meteors, which were observed at the same time by two radars: MAARSY (53.5 MHz) and EISCAT (929 MHz). Because the analysis method described above only requires a single-frequency measurement, independent mass estimates were made using observations from each radar to validate the results. The masses estimated for each radar are strongly linearly correlated; however, the masses derived from EISCAT measurements are on average 1.33 times larger than those derived from MAARSY measurements. This discrepancy has many possible sources, and will be investigated in future work. These results were published in Tarnecki et al (2021).

Having validated the FDTD mass determination method with a set of dual-frequency observations, we then applied it to a set of 166 meteors observed at a single radar frequency (MAARSY) and two wide-field cameras, using the FDTD radar method and applying experimental luminous efficiency fits to calculate photometric masses (derived from our other NSF-funded project). Independent masses are calculated for the radar and each of the cameras, restricted to the coincident region in which both systems are observing at the same time. Results from this work were recently submitted for publication.
